text: the college point yacht club has a
Commodore a crew of officers and private
membership and an annual season opening
ceremony where they raise those nautical
looking triangular flags yet the college
point yacht club is hardly stereotypical
it sits in the shadow of the busy
whitestone bridge and overlooks the
murky waters of the East River its
neighbor to the west is an unsightly
expanse of craggy peers into the East as
a sewage treatment plant many of the
members are retired civil servants and
tradesmen who fix up secondhand boats
it's a work in man chocolate it's you
know nobody's noses up in the air or
anything like that we're not afraid to
get our hands dirty that's the best part
about it you know they put a call out
the members come down and a pitching in
to help out without an in-house mechanic
the club allows members to work on their
own boats in the yard so this time of
year they can be seen painting both
bottoms and repairing sales and engines
and membership there is approximately 90
some members here and we do most of the
work on property ourselves we build our
own docks and stuff like that and the
maintenance on the boat the club is more
blue collar than blue blazer they
gravitate towards the bar in the
clubhouse which is an old barge that was
run aground years ago the bartender is a
retired police officer and the kitchen
work is often handled by retired fireman
there are video games in the clubhouse
and a contribution plate for food for
the fish tank the club's bathroom is
distinguished by a urinal bearing a
decal of Osama bin Laden for target
practice I can't I can't bring myself to
say that it's a yacht club just it's a
great place to go great place for
boaters and people like mindsets then I
always refer to it as a boatyard more so
than the I you know cuz I just come up
get a working class gift I can't say
yeah you don't I mean can't bring myself
to set off the Commodore Tony tondo can
typically be found out in the clubs boat
yard in jeans and work boots and
commanding a fleet of tractors and boat
lifts
these days mr. tondo a retired autoparts
dealer with seven children can be seen
fielding a flood of calls from impatient
members clamoring for their boats to be
lifted out of a winter storage and
lowered off the club's bulkhead what's a
working man's club I mean most of the
people here to work on their own boats
last week everybody wanted to be a boats
in the water and to be memorial day and
I think we launched about 45 boats last
week and we moved about 60 other boats
around the yard so we can launch the 45
volts enough to be careful because you
you know you accidents do happen and
we're not perfect and sometimes you do
scratch somebody's boat well you do not
get over you know if you knock it over
you you have to fix it like an expert
valet Parker mr. tondo can fit the boats
in tightly when storing them for winter
the other guys you know they work with
